author: Special Correspondent
text:
The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) Special Court convicted seven persons, including five retired officials of the State Bank of Mysore (SBM), along with the chairman and a director of a city-based export company, of cheating the bank of Rs. 2.02 crore around 14 years ago.

They have been identified as the then assistant general managers M.S. Seetaram Rao and K. Jagannathan, the then chief manager M.S. Suryanarayana Rao, the then manager T.R. Subba Ramu, and the then deputy manager K. Parthasarathy. All of them were working with the SBM’s Bangalore branch.

The others convicted are M.S.A. Aleem, the then chairman and director of Flora International Ltd., and Anuradha, the then director of the company. They have all been convicted of cheating and forgery.

While the five retired SBM officials have been sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment with a fine of Rs. 1 lakh each, the two directors have been sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment with a fine of Rs. 12 lakh each.

The CBI filed the charge sheet against the seven on September 2002, alleging that the bank officials had colluded with the private company’s directors to cheat the bank of Rs. 2.02 crore.

The company availed itself of the loan for export purposes by providing documents that had been used to taken loans from other banks. The officials were charged with releasing the loan without verification.

The company also defaulted on the loan.
title: Cheating: 5 retired SBM staffers, 2 others convicted
